He became an orphan at the age of two, when he lost his father. Following his father's death, he was raised by his uncle. He read and memorized the entire Qur'an by the time he was nine years old.{{cite web|url=http://www.quran.gov.ae/en/DIHQAPrograms/IslamicPersonality/Pages/FourthSession.aspx |title=Home > English > DIHQA Programs > The Islamic Personality > Fourth Session |publisher=Quran.gov.ae |date= |accessdate=2010-04-11}} He then joined the Institute of Religious Studies at [[Tanta]], and graduated after nine years of study. He moved on to study Islamic Theology at the [[Al-Azhar Theological Seminary|Al-Azhar University]] in [[Cairo]], from which he graduated in 1953. He earned a diploma in [[Arabic]] Language and [[Literature]] in 1958 at the Advanced Arabic Studies Institute. He enrolled in the graduate program in the Department of [[Qur'an]] and [[Sunnah]] Sciences of the Faculty of Religion's Fundamentals (Usul al-Din), and graduated with a Masters degree in Quranic Studies in 1960.[http://www.aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=3&id=13430 Al Qaradawi in Al Azhar] Asharq Aawsat 17/7/2008 In 1962, he was sent by Al-Azhar University to Qatar to head the Qatari Secondary Institute of Religious Studies. He completed his PhD thesis titled ''Zakah and its effect on solving social problems'' in 1973 with First Merit, and was awarded his PhD degree from Al Azhar. In 1977, he laid the foundation for the Faculty of [[Shari'ah]] and [[Islamic Studies]] in the [[University of Qatar]] and became the faculty's dean. In the same year he founded the Centre of Seerah and Sunna Research.{{cite news|last=Abdelhadi |first=Magdi |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/3874893.stm |title=BBC World News Profile of Sheikh Yusuf Qaradawi |publisher=BBC News |date=2004-07-07 |accessdate=2010-04-11}}{{cite web|last=Hamed |first=Ayman |url=http://www.aawsat.com/english/news.asp?section=3&id=13430 |title=Al Qaradawi in Al Azhar |publisher=Aawsat.com |date=2008-07-17 |accessdate=2010-04-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alowaisnet.org/en/winnersbio/abijjffgihfdfhfbej.aspx |title=Dr. Yousef Al Qaradhawi winner Cultural & Scientific Achievements Sixth Circle 1998â1999 |publisher=Alowaisnet.org |date= |accessdate=2010-04-11}} He also served at the Institute of Imams, Egypt under the [[Ministry of Awqaf (Egypt)|Egyptian Ministry of Religious Endowments]] as supervisor before moving back to Doha as Dean of the Islamic Department at the Faculties of Shariah and Education in [[Qatar]], where he continued until 1990.{{cite web|url=http://www.quran.gov.ae/en/News/Lists/News%20Center/DispForm.aspx?ID=82 |title=Profile of Qaradawi |publisher=Quran.gov.ae |date=2009-08-26 |accessdate=2010-04-11}} His next appointment was in Algeria as Chairman of the Scientific Council of Islamic University and Higher Institutions in 1990â91. He returned to Qatar once more as Director of the Seerah and Sunnah Center at Qatar University, a post he still occupies today. Al-Qaradawi is the head of the [[European Council for Fatwa and Research]],an Islamic scholarly entity based in Ireland.[http://www.e-cfr.org/en/ECFR.pdf The European Council for Fatwa and Research] He also serves as the chairman of International Union for Muslim Scholars (IUMS).[http://www.iumsonline.net/about-us/head.html IUMS About us]{{dead link|date=April 2010}} He was imprisoned under [[Farouk of Egypt|King Farouq]] in 1949, then three times during the reign of former President [[Gamal Abdul Nasser]], until he left Egypt for Qatar in 1961. He released a [[dissertation]] on the subject. He listed indications of extremism: #The 1st indication of extremism include [[bigotry]] and intolerance, which make a person adamantly devoted to his own opinions and prejudices, as well as rigidity, which deprives him of clarity of vision regarding the interests of other human beings, or the purposes of [[Shariah]], or the circumstances of age. Such a person does not allow any opportunity for dialogue with others so that he may compare his opinion with theirs, and chooses to follow what appears to him most sound.[http://www.witness-pioneer.org/vil/Books/Q_RE/ch1pre.htm#3.%20Manifestations%20of%20Extremism "Islamic Awakening between Rejection and Extremism"] www.witness-pioneer.org #The 2nd indication of extremism manifests in a continuous commitment to excessiveness, and in attempts to force others to do likewise, despite the fact that Allah has not commanded it, and the existence of good reasons to make things easy. A person motivated by piety and caution may however, if he so wishes, choose a hard-line opinion in some matters and on certain occasions. But this should not become so habitual that he rejects advice when he needs it. #The 3rd indication of extremism is the out-of-time and out-of-place religious excessiveness and overburdening of others, ''i.e.'' when applying Islamic principles to people in non-Muslim countries or to people who have only recently converted to Islam, as well as to newly committed Muslims. With all these, emphasis should not be put on either minor or controversial issues, but on fundamentals. Endeavours should be made to correct their concepts and understanding of Islam before anything else. #The 4th indication of extremism manifests itself in harshness in the treatment of people, roughness in the manner of approach, and crudeness in calling people to Islam, all which are contrary to the teachings of the Qur'an and Sunnah. ;Sufism Al-Qaradawi has been an avid caller to what he calls "Islamic [[Sufism]]", praising those who practice it as pious.{{cite web|url=http://www.sunnah.org/tasawwuf/scholr39.htm |title=On Tassawuf Shaykh Yusuf al-Qaradawi |publisher=Sunnah.org |date= |accessdate=2010-04-11}} He has also been a staunch defender of the [[Ashari]] school of belief within Islam, going so far as to claim that the whole Muslim world follows this school as well as all Muslim religious schools in the world.[http://www.youngmuslims.ca/biographies/display.asp?ID=3 Al Ghazaly Man of Da'wah]{{dead link|date=April 2010}} ;Shi'ites Al-Qaradawi has also described [[Shi'ites]] as [[heresy|heretics]] ("mubtadi'oun").{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2008/916/eg5.htm |title=The politics of sects |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date=2008-10-05 |accessdate=2010-04-11}} Fellow member of International union of Muslim Scholars, [[Mohammad Salim Al-Awa]] criticized Qaradawi for promoting divisions among Muslims.ibid. In response, the [[Iranian Press Agency]] has described Qaradawi as "a spokesman for âinternational [[Freemasonry]] and [[rabbi]]s".[http://www.economist.com/research/backgrounders/displaystory.cfm?story_id=12305381 Try to be nice about each other, A Sunni preacher upsets the Shias] Sep 25th 2008, CAIRO, From The Economist print edition Qaradawi accused what he called "heretical" Shias of "invading" Sunni countries.{{cite news|title=Inflential Sunni cleric speaks of Shiite 'invasion'|author=(AFP)|url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5g-I5N5oznQqpvBVxaDnjD-uJyswA|newspaper=AFP|date=Sep 18, 2008|accessdate=February 15, 2011}} ====Non-Muslims==== Al-Qaradawi has strongly pressed for dialogue with Non-Muslims. He also puts emphasis on conversations with the West, including Jews, Christians, and [[secularists]]. He writes that this effort should differentiate itself from a [[debate]], for the latter does not often result in mutual cooperation. In his book titled ''Priorities of The Islamic Movement in The Coming Phase'', he recounts his experience: {{bquote|I will never forget what one of the participants, a [[Christian nationalism|nationalist Christian]], said to me at the lunch table. He said, "We have changed our opinion about you completely". I asked, "And what was your opinion?" He replied, "that you are a hard-liner and a fanatic". I said, "Where did you get this idea about me? He answered, "I don't know, but, frankly, that was our impression about you". I asked "And now?" He said, "Now we have learned through seeing, hearing, discussion and direct contact what has changed this unfair idea about you completely. We now see you as a man who respects logic, refers to reason and knows how to listen to the other opinion as a man who is not stubborn or adamant, but extremely flexible and tolerant". What I want to convey by telling this story is that direct contact and reasonable, quiet dialogue that is held on equal footing is in the interest of the Islamic Movement, which stands to gain from it and will lose nothing at all in it.[http://www.witness-pioneer.org/vil/Books/Q_Priorities/ch4p1-1.htm#The%20Dialogue%20With%20Rational%20Secularists "Qaradawi's on Dialogue with Others"] www.witness-pioneer.org}} Regarding the rights and citizenship of non-Muslim minorities, Qaradawi has said: {{cquote|those people who live under the protection of an Islamic government enjoy special privileges. They are referred to as "the Protected People" (ahl al-dhimma or [[dhimmi]]s), meaning that [[Allah]], [[Muhammad|His Messenger]] ... and the community of Muslims have made a covenant with them that they may live in safety and security under the Islamic government. Therefore, he was not successful in many of his hard-hitting opinions. This was the reason of my disagreement with him despite the old friendship between us."{{cite web|author= By Alaa Bayoumi |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/focus/2010/03/201031763554123901.html |title=Focus - The battle for Al-Azhar |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2010-03-17 |accessdate=2010-04-11}} ===Entry into western countries=== Al-Qaradawi has been banned from entering the [[United States]] since 1999 and the [[United Kingdom]] since 2008,{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Muslim cleric not allowed into UK | date=2008-02-07 | publisher= | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/7232398.stm | work =BBC News | pages = | accessdate = 2008-02-08 | language = }} though he visited London in 2004.[http://ctc.usma.edu/atlas/Atlas-ResearchCompendium.pdf Militant Ideology Atlas], Combating Terrorism Center, West Point In July 2003 he visited [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]], for a conference at the [[Stockholm Mosque]] arranged by the [[Muslim Association of Sweden]]. During the conference al-Qaradawi expressed his support for suicide attacks against Israeli civilians, calling the fight against the Israeli occupation of the Palestinian Territories a "necessary [[Jihad]]".{{cite news |first = Fredrik |last = Malm |authorlink = Fredrik Malm |title = Massmordspredikan i svensk moskÃ© |url = http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=572&a=172705 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20041104021932/http://www.dn.se/DNet/jsp/polopoly.jsp?d=572&a=172705 |archivedate = 2004-11-04 |publisher = [[Dagens Nyheter]] |date = August 21, 2003 |language = Swedish}} ===Fatwa controversy with MEMRI=== The [[Middle East Media Research Institute]] (MEMRI) (citing [[Asharq Al-Awsat]]), alleges that al-Qaradawi issued a Fatwa following the [[Iraqi insurgency]], saying,
All of the Americans in Iraq are combatants, there is no difference between civilians and soldiers, and one should fight them, since the American civilians came to Iraq in order to serve the occupation. The abduction and killing of Americans in Iraq is a [religious] obligation so as to cause them to leave Iraq immediately. The mutilation of corpses [however] is forbidden in Islam.{{cite web | url = http://www.memri.org/bin/articles.cgi?Page=subjects&Area=jihad&ID=SP79404#_edn1 | title = memri.org | accessdate = 2007-06-18 | publisher = }}
Al-Qaradawi, however, denies this allegation:
I have not published a Fatwa on this issue. At the Egyptian Journalists' Union a few days ago I was asked about the permissibility of fighting against the occupation in Iraq, and I answered that it is permitted. Afterwards I was asked concerning the American civilians in Iraq and I merely responded with the question â are there American civilians in Iraq? It is a matter of common knowledge that in Fatwas such as these I do not use the word "killing" but rather I say "struggle," which is a more comprehensive word than the word "killing" and whose meaning is not necessarily to kill. In addition, I have condemned the taking of hostages on a number of occasions in the past and have demanded that they be released and that their lives not be threatened.MEMRI as above, citing [[al-Hayat]]
[[Shaker Al-Nabulsi]], a former Muslim{{cite web | url = http://www.memri.org/bin/articles.cgi?Page=subjects&Area=jihad&ID=SP79404#_edn20 | title =Reactions to Sheikh Al-Qaradhawi's Fatwa Calling for the Abduction and Killing of American Civilians in Iraq | accessdate = 2008-10-13 | publisher = memri.org}} who writes for the liberal site Ethal, called for the creation of a petition to the [[UN]] calling to put Qaradawi and his like on trial for incitement and support of [[terrorism]]. ===Alcohol fatwa controversy=== Al-Qaradawi issued a fatwa in 2008 stating that the consumption of tiny amounts of [[alcohol]] (<0.5% concentration or 5/1000) was acceptable for Muslims.{{cite news|last=Harrison |first=Frances |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/7342425.stm |title=Alcohol fatwa sparks controversy |publisher=BBC News |date=2008-04-11 |accessdate=2010-04-11}} The statement was made regarding [[energy drink]]s, where fermentation occurs naturally as part of the production process. This does not contradict with the widespread view that consuming alcohol is totally forbidden to Muslims. (chapter 5: verses 90â91). The fermentation in this process is natural and unavoidable, similarly it is an extremely small proportion.{{cite web|url=http://www.usc.edu/dept/MSA/quran/005.qmt.html#005.090 |title=Qur'an Chapter 50: Al Maeda, verse 90 |publisher=Usc.edu |date= |accessdate=2010-04-11}} ==Awards and recognition== [[Image:Book on qaradawi.png|thumb|right|''The Global Mufti: The Phenomenon of Yusuf al-Qaradawi'',a book on Qaradawi published by Columbia Press]] Al-Qaradawi has been awarded by various countries and institutions for his contributions to Islamic society. The Amir presents the State Acknowledgement Award to Dr. Sheikh Yusuf Al Qaradawi for his contributions in the field of Islamic Studies |publisher=Diwan.gov.qa |date= |accessdate=2010-04-11}} The Qatar Faculty of Islamic Studies, part of the [[Qatar Foundation|Qatar Foundation for Education, Science and Community Development]], instituted the "Sheikh Yusuf Al Qaradawi Scholarships" in 2009, awarding them to five students each year for post-graduate studies.[http://www.qfis.edu.qa/files/pdf/Microsoft%20Word%20-%20QFIS_Scholarships%202009-2010.pdf Qatar Faculty of Islamic Studies (QFIS)] It also named after him its newly established research centre, The Qaradawi Center for Islamic Moderation and Renewal.{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/572720-qatar-centre-spreads-moderate-islam-dialogue |title=Qatar centre spreads moderate Islam, dialogue |publisher=Arabianbusiness.com |date=2009-11-07 |accessdate=2010-04-11}}{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=314242&version=1&template_id=57 |title=Qaradawi centre vows to fight extremism |publisher=Gulf-times.com |date=2009-12-09 |accessdate=2010-04-11}} He is a trustee of the [[Oxford University]] Center for Islamic Studies and has been named as the technical consultant for a multi-million dollar [[English-language]] film about [[Prophet Muhammed]] produced by [[Barrie Osborne]]. A 2008 ''[[Foreign Policy]]'' poll put him at No.3 in the list of the Top 20 Public Intellectuals worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2008/06/16/the_world_s_top_20_public_intellectuals |title=The Worldâs Top 20 Public Intellectuals |publisher=Foreignpolicy.com |date=2008-06-16 |accessdate=2010-04-11}} ==Books== ===Fiqh az Zakat=== Al -Qaradawi has authored more than 80 books and his academic style and objective thought are considered to be some of the main characteristics of his works. His most famous work is ''The Lawful and Prohibited in Islam''. Professor Mustafa al-Zarqa declared that owning a copy of it was "the duty of every Muslim family." His book ''Fiqh al-Zakat'' is considered by some as the most comprehensive work in the area of [[zakat]]. [[Abul Ala Maududi]] commented on it as "the book of this century in Islamic jurisprudence (fiqh)" The prominent [[Deobandi]] [[Islamic scholar]] [[Muhammad Taqi Usmani]], said this about the work:[http://www.suhaibwebb.com/islam-studies/yusuf-al-qaradawi-as-i-have-known-him-by-mufti-taqi-uthmani-h/ YÅ«suf al-QaradÄwÄ«, as I Have Known Him]
The first book that read in its entirety of his works is his valuable book Fiqh al-Zakat, and I benefitted much from this great, encyclopedic, rewarding work through which the author did a great service to the second of the pillars of Islam, in a way that the umma needs today, when it comes to the application of zakat at the level of the individual and the group. Indeed this work manifested the genius of its author, and his inventive methodology, not only in the clarification of issues pertaining to zakat and their compilation, but in stimulating research in contemporary topics that no one before him had touched upon, and basing them upon the principles fiqh and its jurisprudential theory.

And Muslims should recognise that technological change means that media and information systems are as much a part of the jihadist repertoire as are guns.
